German[edit]

Etymology 1[edit]

From Old High German zol, from Proto-Germanic *tullō (“what is counted or told”). Alternatively from Medieval Latin toloneum, from Latin telōnēum.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /tsɔl/
  • Audio
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

Zoll m (genitive Zolls or Zolles, plural Zölle)

  1. custom (duty collected at the borders)
  2. customs (authority collecting that duty)

Declension[edit]

Declension of Zoll
singularplural
indef.def.noundef.noun
nominativeeinderZolldieZölle
genitiveeinesdesZolles,
Zolls		derZölle
dativeeinemdemZoll,
Zolle1		denZöllen
accusativeeinendenZolldieZölle
1Now uncommon, see notes
Derived terms[edit]
  • zollpflichtig

Etymology 2[edit]

Noun[edit]

Zoll n (genitive Zolls, plural Zoll)

  1. unit of length (if used nowadays it equals an inch)
Declension[edit]
Declension of Zoll

indef.def.noundef.noun

Luxembourgish[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Old High German zol. Cognate with German Zoll, English toll, Dutch tol, Icelandic tollur, Swedish tull.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /tsol/
    • Rhymes: -ol

Noun[edit]

Zoll m (plural Zoll)

  1. custom, duty
  2. customs
